close_symbols: struct MHD_InterimParams_ (fields: fdset_size_set, fdset_size, listen_fd_set, listen_fd, server_addr_len_set, pserver_addr_set, pserver_addr, server_addr_len)
struct MHD_Daemon (fields: options, fdset_size, fdset_size_set_by_app, listen_fd, listen_is_unix, port)
underlying socket descriptor type (typedef of listen_fd / params->listen_fd)
explanation:
For MISRA C rule checking of invariant controlling expressions we must know which expressions are compile-time constants or tautologies and which depend on runtime data. Each listed symbol is referenced by a controlling expression in process_interim_params or changes which expressions are compiled in/out:

- struct MHD_InterimParams_ (fields...): almost every if/else tests fields of this struct (fdset_size_set, fdset_size, listen_fd_set, listen_fd, server_addr_len_set, pserver_addr_set, pserver_addr, server_addr_len). You need their types, signedness and semantics to determine whether the tests (e.g. if (params->fdset_size_set), if (0 >= params->fdset_size), if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == params->listen_fd), if (0 > params->listen_fd), and server_addr_len checks) can be invariant.

- struct MHD_Daemon (fields...): expressions read d->options and other fields (e.g. d->listen_fd, d->fdset_size). The type and initial/possible values of these fields affect whether bitmask tests or comparisons are invariant.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_(d): this macro/function controls a branch. If it expands to a compile-time constant (e.g. when thread support is compiled out) the controlling expression could be invariant; its definition is needed to decide that.

- MHD_D_IS_USING_POLL_(d): same rationale as above for the polling-related branch.

- HAS_FD_SETSIZE_OVERRIDABLE: presence/absence of this preprocessor symbol changes which code (and which controlling expressions) are compiled. Whether the FD_SETSIZE override path exists affects invariance analysis.

- FD_SETSIZE (value and type): used in numeric comparison with params->fdset_size. Its numeric value and type (usually int) are needed to determine whether comparisons could be constant/always true or false in combination with params' type and possible values.

- HAS_SIGNED_SOCKET: controls whether the branch with 'else if (0 > params->listen_fd)' is present. If undefined the expression is not present; if defined the comparison's validity/invariance depends on the socket type—so the symbol is required.

- MHD_INVALID_SOCKET (constant and its type): used to compare/assign listen_fd; knowing its value (e.g. -1, INVALID_SOCKET) and type is necessary to see if comparisons (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == params->listen_fd) can be invariant or if they are well-typed.

- underlying socket descriptor type (typedef of listen_fd / params->listen_fd): the signedness and width of the socket type determine the semantics of numeric comparisons like 0 > params->listen_fd and comparisons with MHD_INVALID_SOCKET; unsigned types can make such comparisons always false or introduce invariants.

- MHD_USE_NO_LISTEN_SOCKET (option flag value and type): used in bitmask tests (d->options & MHD_USE_NO_LISTEN_SOCKET). To decide if that controlling expression can be invariant we need the flag value and to know the type/possible values of d->options.

(Other items in the function such as MHD_DLOG, MHD_socket_close_, HAVE_MESSAGES, _MHD_UNKNOWN only affect logging or non-controlling-code and are not required to determine whether the controlling expressions are invariant.)
